qas.question: By What time period was the Sahara dry like it is today?
What was the main reason that the Sahara became so   dry?
What area is known for having the majority of the trade?
When did the Sahara become accessible to humans?
What features of the Nile made it ideal for trading?
Where did people trade in the Sahara before the aridification?
What caused the shift in the earth's orbit?

plausible_answers.text: the remaining settlements mainly being concentrated around the numerous oases

qas.question: How did humans cause the aridification of the Sahara?

context: By <a0_0><b3_0>3400 BCE<b3_0/><a0_0/>, the Sahara was as dry as it is today, due to <a1_0><b6_0>reduced precipitation and higher temperatures<b6_0/><a1_0/> resulting from a shift in the Earth's orbit. As a result of this aridification, it became a largely impenetrable barrier to humans, with <b7_0>the remaining settlements mainly being concentrated around the numerous oases<b7_0/> that dot the landscape. Little trade or commerce is known to have passed through the interior in subsequent periods, the only major exception being <a2_0><b5_0>the Nile Valley<b5_0/><a2_0/>. The Nile, however, was impassable at <b4_0>several cataracts<b4_0/>, making trade and contact by boat difficult.
